Description: Fragment from lower part of body of North Ionian pottery bowl. Interior glazed with worn decoration in added red and white; bud and perhaps tongue above, lotus flower below. Exterior: traces of upper frieze, one hoof, a dot rosette; below, between bands with aded red bands lined in white, a goat springing to right, looking back, and hind leg of another; rosettes, half rosettes, and cruciform rosettes; red on goat's hind quarter and chest/shoulder; top of third frieze below. White slip.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by British School at Athens. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Probably part of the bowl British Museum 1888,0601.534.

Kardara places this fragment in her 'mixed technique' style (1963, 199-248) and for the attribution see her 213-15. The springing goat looking back is associated with Late Wild Goat Style cf. Walter-Karydi 1973, 143 no 918 (Hermitage 17567), a North Ionian shoulder-neck amphora from Berezan. For the goat in this position see Kardara 1963 253-4 and R.M. Cook, Dupont 1998, 53-4. For the rosettes see Schiering 1957 fig 3 (botom left) and row 7 (2) and fig. 2 row 6 (1). Kardara 1963 pl. 13 ß and Walter-Karydi 1973, 143 no. 900 (Palermo from Selinus) and pl. 108. T.J. Smith, "East Greek Pottery in the Collection of the British School at Athens", BSA 104, 2009, 347, fig. 2
The number '4' is written in ink on the interior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Smith 2009 / East Greek Pottery in the Collection of the British School at Athens (p. 347, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.925)
